text: I'm a developer (have built multiple SaaS apps from the ground up) and tried to set up our new marketing site on Webflow before giving up as it was one of the most infuriating platforms I've ever used.

elements.text: I'm a developer (have built multiple SaaS apps from the ground up) and tried to set up our new marketing site on Webflow before giving up as it was one of the most infuriating platforms I've ever used.

text: Webflow _looks_ very good but I feel that from a product perspective it allows for complexity in design execution in a really unsustainable way.

elements.text: Webflow
looks
very good but I feel that from a product perspective it allows for complexity in design execution in a really unsustainable way.

text: Strategy question for a new blog for a website (strong DA): do you start by creating content that focuses a lot on your product competitive advantage? Or do you start by creating different types of content (BOFU, case studies, product related blogs) and then focusing based on those results?

text:
Hey <@U022P09NXS7>,

I think you’re talking about Simplified UI. This type of content is designed in such a way that it is easy to follow, and is able to withstand future UI tweaks.

I work at Content Beta, a software product video company. We’ve helped ManyChat, Dynamic Yield and 60 other B2B SaaS create engaging product marketing and demo videos to generate more MQLs. Feel free to check out examples of our work to see if we’re a good fit for you: <https://www.contentbeta.com/video-examples/> 

Happy to connect.

attachments.fallback: Content Beta: Video Examples | Video Production Service for SaaS & Software Business
attachments.text: Frictionless Product Marketing and Customer Training Video to get more demo requests and faster onboarding.
attachments.title: Video Examples | Video Production Service for SaaS & Software Business

text:
Question for the group: do you have a single calendar that encompasses all of your marketing movements? What app is it and how well does it work for you?

We are currently divided between Asana, Notion, and Google Calendar and are unable to agree on a single tool because each has their own drawbacks that make them unsuitable to be the sole Marketing bible

elements.text:
Question for the group: do you have a single calendar that encompasses all of your marketing movements? What app is it and how well does it work for you?

We are currently divided between Asana, Notion, and Google Calendar and are unable to agree on a single tool because each has their own drawbacks that make them unsuitable to be the sole Marketing bible

text: I'd tell you about how I live my life on Trello but doesn't sound like you need a new tool in that mixing pot!

elements.text: I'd tell you about how I live my life on Trello but doesn't sound like you need a new tool in that mixing pot!

text: At my previous company we used Airtable and that worked pretty well for us (we used it as as calendar and content database).

text:
What are the drawbacks you are finding that are making the other tools unsuitable? Do you have specific things you want the tool to do?

If you are looking for more of a visual calendar with customizations to channels/tactics, etc we built <http://PromoPrep.com|PromoPrep.com> for this purpose.

text:
most of the team seems to like Notion for its calendar function, (and its what our product team uses) but it has no notification ability

On the surface asana is good for building out a project but you can only assign one person to a task, there are no depenedncies, and you can’t put a start date only deadlines

most of the team seems to like Notion for its calendar function, (and its what our product team uses) but it has no notification ability

On the surface asana is good for building out a project but you can only assign one person to a task, there are no depenedncies, and you can’t put a start date only deadlines

text: You can set reminders in the date field and in any text format with the @remind syntax in Notion. You can also @ team members

elements.text: You can set reminders in the date field and in any text format with the @remind syntax in Notion. You can also @ team members

text: the general UX of Notions is also difficult to deal with. it’s not a purpose built project management tool. it’s a hash of different features with the same color scheme

elements.text: the general UX of Notions is also difficult to deal with. it’s not a purpose built project management tool. it’s a hash of different features with the same color scheme

text:
We use dependencies within Asana for this, subtasks for the various assignees/stages, and add start dates and end dates to articles. Are you folks on a plan that doesn’t have the dependency and start date features? I wasn’t even aware the other plans might not have them.

For the record though—I despite Asana.

elements.text:
We use dependencies within Asana for this, subtasks for the various assignees/stages, and add start dates and end dates to articles. Are you folks on a plan that doesn’t have the dependency and start date features? I wasn’t even aware the other plans might not have them.

For the record though—I despite Asana.

text: AirTable is my favourite Single Source of Truth tool. But we use Notion because the rest of our company uses Notion religiously to document everything. It's fine, but I find it easy to lose things.

elements.text: AirTable is my favourite Single Source of Truth tool. But we use Notion because the rest of our company uses Notion religiously to document everything. It's fine, but I find it easy to lose things.

text:
I'm using a relatively new tool, Narrato - <https://narrato.io/|https://narrato.io/>, which has its own content calendar and workflow board. It's great for assigning tasks and tracking project statuses. It sends an email notification every time a task is assigned to a team member.

Wherever I need reminders I rely on Google Calendar. 

This system seems to be working fine for me.

attachments.fallback: Narrato WorkSpace - Content Creation & Workflow Software
attachments.text: Narrato Workspace is a content creation, collaboration, workflow and project management tool that brings all your content processes and people on a single platform.
attachments.title: Narrato WorkSpace - Content Creation & Workflow Software

elements.text: I'm using a relatively new tool, Narrato -
https://narrato.io/

, which has its own content calendar and workflow board. It's great for assigning tasks and tracking project statuses. It sends an email notification every time a task is assigned to a team member.

Wherever I need reminders I rely on Google Calendar. 

This system seems to be working fine for me.

text:
Definitely start with educational and high-value content. In my experience, companies I've worked with always start out by posting more of tips, guides and other content that addresses audience pain points, not very self promotional.

Then we’ve gradually moved a step further with case studies and FAQ blogs on the product.

elements.text:

Then we’ve gradually moved a step further with case studies and FAQ blogs on the product.

text:
Wondering if anyone has had success with sponsored content from a B2B brand awareness perspective? I realize it depends on audience but looking at more general publications like Boston Globe, Financial Post, Forbes, Diginomica, etc. that target executive decision makers.

Anyone have any recommendations or red flags?
